item.name: Network CLOSE_WAIT connections
item.description: The remote end has shut down, waiting for the socket to close.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network CLOSING connections
item.description: Both sockets are shut down but we still don't have all our data sent.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network ESTABLISHED connections
item.description: The socket has an established connection.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network FIN_WAIT2 connections
item.description: Connection is closed, and the socket is waiting for a shutdown from the remote end.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network LAST_ACK connections
item.description: The remote end has shut down, and the socket is closed. Waiting for acknowledgement.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network LISTEN connections
item.description: The socket is listening for incoming connections.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network SYN_RECV connections
item.description: A connection request has been received from the network.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network SYN_SENT connections
item.description: The socket is actively attempting to establish a connection.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network TIME_WAIT connections
item.description: The socket is waiting after close to handle packets still in the network.

master_item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Network Interface Packets Received Discarded
item.description: The number of received packets that contained errors, preventing them from being delivered to a higher-level protocol.

item.name: Network Interface Packets Received Errors
item.description: The number of received packets that contained errors, preventing them from being delivered to a higher-level protocol.

item.name: Network Interface Packets Outbound Discarded
item.description: Use this counter to determine if the network is saturated. If this counter continuously increases, it might indicate that a network is so busy that the network buffers cannot keep up with the outbound flow of packets.

item.name: Network Interface Packets Outbound Errors
item.description: The number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted due to errors.

item.name: Context Switches/sec
item.description: Indicates that the kernel has switched the thread it is running on a processor. A context switch occurs each time a new thread runs, and each time one thread takes over from another. A large number of threads is likely to increase the number of context switches. Context switches allow multiple threads to share time slices on the processors, but they also interrupt the processor and might reduce overall system performance, especially on multiprocessor computers. You should also observe the patterns of context switches over time.

item.name: Memory Pool Paged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the paged pool. This is an area of system memory used for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used. There may be a memory leak if this value is greater than 250MB (or 170MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2020 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Memory Pool Nonpaged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
item.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limit—in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: I/O Read Operations/sec
item.description: The number of read input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Reads directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: I/O Write Operations/sec
item.description: The number of write input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Writes directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: I/O Data Operations/sec
item.description: These counters count all I/O activity generated to include file, network and device I/Os. These analyses check when processes are doing more than 1,000 I/O’s per second and flag it as a warning. These analyses are best used in correlation with other analyses such as disk analysis to determine which processes might be involved in the I/O activity.

item.name: I/O Other Operations/sec
item.description: The number of input/output operations generated by a process that are neither reads nor writes, including file, network, and device I/Os. An example of this type of operation would be a control function. I/O Others directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk Queue Length
item.description: This indicates how many I/O operations are waiting for the hard drive to become available. If the value here is larger than the two times the number of spindles, that means the disk itself may be the bottleneck.

item.name: Processor % Load
item.description:
"\Processor(_Total)\% Processor Time” can go up to 100 because it’s the average CPU usage across all CPUs.
old value = perf_counter["\230(_Total)\4086",1]

item.name: CPU user time
item.description:
This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in user mode. If this value is high, the server is busy with the application. One possible solution here is to optimize the application that is using up the processor resources.
\Processor(_Total)\% User Time

item.name: CPU system time
item.description:
The percentage of time a thread was running in privileged mode (executing kernel or sytem routines).
\Processor(_Total)\% Privileged Time

item.name: Interrupts per second
item.description: \Processor(_Total)\Interrupts/sec

item.name: Processor % DPC Time
item.description:
Determines how much time the processor is spending processing DPCs. DPCs originate when the processor performs tasks requiring immediate attention, and then defers the remainder of the task to be handled at lower priority. DPCs represent further processing of client requests.
\Processor(_Total)\% DPC Time

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description:
This measures the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interruptions during specific sample intervals. This counter indicates a possible hardware issue if the value is greater than 15 percent.
\Processor(_Total)\% Interrupt Time

item.name: Processor % C1 Time
item.description:
C1 is a power saving mode in a CPU. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C1 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C1 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.
\Processor(_Total)\% C1 Time

item.name: Processor % C2 Time
item.description:
C2 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than C1. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C2 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C2 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.
\Processor(_Total)\% C2 Time

item.name: Processor % C3 Time
item.description:
C3 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than both C1 and C2. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C3 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C3 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.
\Processor(_Total)\% C3 Time

item.name: Number of logged in users
item.description: Number of users who are currently logged in.

item.name: Network connections
item.key: system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"Get-NetTCPConnection | Group-Object State | Select-Object Name, Count | FT -HideTableHeaders\"","wait"]

item.name: Process with topmost CPU usage
item.description:
Shows, in decreasing order the processes that are eating CPU. The number of process shown can be customized by setting the TOP parameter
system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"& {(query user).count -1}\""]
system.run["powershell -NoProfile -Command \"& {Get-Process | Sort-Object CPU -desc | Select-Object -first 5}\""]

item.name: OS Version
item.description: wmi.get[root\cimv2,'select Caption+OSArchitecture+Version from Win32_OperatingSystem']

item.name: Zabbix agent command line
item.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PathName from Win32_Service where displayname="Zabbix Agent"]
